content.body: and figcaption is better than fcaption
I can see an argument for both "label" and "summary"
I like the way <summary> quite directly suggests what it should be, for maximum accessibility.
But it's not necessarily a summary, is it?
Though it is clickable like a <label>, <summary> just matches better in my head.
It's pretty close.
Or rather, *should* be pretty close if <details> is used correctly.
Note: I consider heading-like content to be close to a summary.
I think summary sort of works as an alternative to figcaption, though its name would clash semantically with the table summary attribute, which is certainly not a caption
but I don't see how summary works for details
Lachy: Check http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/interactive-elements.html#the-details-element
Note how the prose uses the term "summary" to describe the toggler bit.
yeah, I saw that. I'm not sure that's a good description for it
http://www.w3.org/mid/1263225612.26294.2.camel@chacal is interesting
in the spec example pictures (from the Mac OS X Finder), it's probably more accurate to call the short bits a "label" rather than a "summary"
Hixie: what is interesting about it?
Hixie: I think what Philippe is saying is:
that the new rdfa group _doesn't_ include the text/html rdfa stuff
ah
othermaciej, what are those controls called in OS X?
I was expecting that "RDFa in HTML" would stay an HTML WG deliverable
Lachy: disclosure widgets is what i've heard them called
Interesting, doesn't that make some of the statements about the pointed-out lacks in RDFa being addressed in 1.1 moot?
the term for the triangle part is "disclosure triangle"
oh, yeah, I remember reading "disclosure triangles" in the Apple HIG
looking up what the control itself is called officially
Or does it just mean the group responsible for it is different, but they'll still describe integration with HTML as well as XML?
Hixie, did you make those Pillar magazine graphics?
yes
that's my cat
yeah, I know
I recognised it
TabAtkins, RDFa in HTML never did anything but said how to integrate it, right?  I assume it will just say how to integrate 1.1 just as much.
Lachy: "disclosure triangle" is the only term, the control is provided as just the spinny triangle, and not as the whole integrated thing that incorporates the contents
AryehGregor: Well, at the very least it'll have to be updated for the various incompatible changes that 1.1 is making.
I don't see how that's relevant to the statements you referred to, though.
It is probably me just misreading the statement, so don't worry about it.
Oh man, I've been off work for 15 minutes!  Woo!
goes to play more Saints Row.
Hixie: I keep accidentally opening http://damowmow.com/playground/htmlwg/chart.html in released Safari instead of trunk
Hixie: I gotta get that bug into a software update for my own sanity
hah
Hixie: is it useful to have separate "HTML5 spec bugs" and "HTML5 spec proposals" components in w3c bugzilla?
I'm thinking of suggesting they be folded into one
no, but please don't change that because that would break all my queries
all my queries, bookmarks, scripts, etc, use those two components
I see
(similarly, please don't add new components)
is it possible to make, say, the "proposals" one closed to new bugs without removing it fully?
dunno
is it causing a problem?
not really, just minor annoyance when forming a query by hand
ah
I do think separate drafts should have separate components, cause otherwise it's pretty hard to separately track when each gets to 0 bugs in a non-terminal state
well if there are other editors, they should get components, sure, but for drafts i edit i treat them all as one draft anyway
so it's moot
so I'm seeing 231 bugs resolved since the start of the month
67 still open
incoming rate must be out of control
since there were fewer than 200 open on the 1st
incoming rate grew significantly higher than i expected, yes
though i don't track that
so i don't have numbers
115 created since the start of the month
Jeez, that's 10 a day.
FWIW Hixie's accept/reject rate is still around 50% of the non-garbage bugs
(where by "garbage" I mean duplicate or invalid)
I looked at some past months and the rate seems to be slowly going down over time
the highest I found was 70%
as in i'm rejecting more?
that seems like pretty much whatI would expect for a maturing spec
yes, you seem to be rejecting more percentage-wise than in, say, July
i'd expect the rate to go the other way, actually, because the problems should be getting more trivial (e.g. reviewers should be moving from "this doesn't work" to "this is misspelt")
well some reviewers are still submitting requests for new features
there might be a better correlation of rate vs reporter than rate vs time
but you're right, I could imagine it going the other way if the proportion of editorial issues was increasing as one might expect
possible - I did not try to measure that cause it would be too much work :-)
since we are moving into a fluid versionless HTML - will we also move into a versionless web applications?

and decoupling the API endpoints from the UI URLs would suck, too
well, I think I'm going to wait and see how things develop
although by HTML6, I need to rearrange the UI anyway

well, HTML5.next
HTML5 is HTML5.next

though it could be that only Bing's Finland region sucks

but when i search for a restaurant, i do

(when outside Helsinki, that is. for Helsinki, there's a specialized service that beats Google on restaurants)
maybe search engines could figure out from the query whether to be locale-sensitive or not
I believe they try with varying levels of success
hmm
Bing IS better than Google
I should pay more attention to Asa

my search for "empress garden" returns the correct Auckland restaurant as the top hit (actually the top several hits) ... I haven't searched for it before

it should be a parameter for text/html instead
zcorpan__: Wouldn't that defeat the point?
If a user could visit the supposedly-sandboxed content by a direct URL, rather than via the iframe, and their (legacy) browser rendered the page, the user would be vulnerable to malicious content
Oh, but I suppose legacy browsers will ignore the sandbox attribute on iframe anyway, so maybe we don't care about them
or we should have <sandboxediframe>

hsivonen: probably global s/html/php/ when switching file extensions...
The sphere mapped to a rectangle?
zcorpan__: in theory, yes, but is the perf sufficient?
There's a lot of http://philip.html5.org/data/doctypes.html#%3c%21doctype_doctype_public_%22-%2f%2fw3c%2f%2fdtd_html_4.0_transitional%2f%2fen%22%3e
How would you do a sphere -> rect (or opposite) mapping in 2D canvas?
hsivonen: no idea
Dashiva: by pixel, I guess
Dashiva: or by slicing the image and drawing approximation with a 2D matrix
I expect it'd be really hard to make it look good in 2D canvas, because you can only do affine transforms, so you can't even do a decent textured polygon mesh
the above Flash thingy doesn't look so great when there are straight lines in the view
like the railing of the bridge
That demo already seems to have really dodgy perspective
since the image seems to stretch when it's near the edges
3d effects don't have to be perfect

I think you can draw an arbitrary texture triangle onto an arbitrary screen triangle (by computing an appropriate transform matrix), so I suppose you could pre-compute a spherical triangle mesh that covers the screen, and map each triangle onto texture coordinates depending on view angle, so maybe it wouldn't be too bad
but you'd have to use lots of triangles

Just in the context menu.

AryehGregor: does the MediaWiki API provide any way to extract sections from a page?
MikeSmith, um, let me see.
OK, to be clear, what I mean is, if I give it a section title, can I get the contents of that section back
I'd imagine you could do it by section number.  Section title is probably less reliable, those aren't guaranteed to be unique and section 0 has no title.
doesn't usually use the API, so is looking at the docs
Hmm.  The closest I see is this: http://en.wikipedia.org/w/api.php?action=parse&page=HTML5&prop=sections
text/sandboxed-html doesn't seem to have very nice graceful degradation.

I guess you could retrieve that, retrieve the wikitext, and slice out the bytes given.  If you want it to be HTML, you can then feed that back to the parser.  Of course, that will give weird results if any tags straddle sections.
The person to ask in RoanKattouw, he's the API guy, but he seems not to be on IRC right now.
I assume that's probably considered a feature that current UAs won't accidentally interpret the HTML, but Firefox popping up a save dialog to users isn't very nice.
Safari seems to have the best fallback, which is to treat it as text/plain
If your site wants to work in legacy browsers without exposing those users to XSS attacks, the site will have to sanitise the HTML anyway before it can be used in <iframe sandbox>
in which case serving the same content as standalone text/html to legacy browsers wouldn't introduce any new dangers
It only makes a difference for sandbox-supporting browsers, where the sandbox layer of defence would be lost if the content was accessed outside of its iframe
yeah, I realise that. I'm just concerned that this will limit adoption among sites, since they usually need to maintain compat with older browsers for a few years after they've been made obsolete

So I guess something like text/html;sandbox=1 would be better because it will work in legacy browsers without introducing new vulnerabilities, and will allow sandbox-supporting browsers to apply extra defences to it
and I don't know any site that would want users to inadvertently save the file and then possibly open it wondering what it is
(But, on the other hand, people will add ;sandbox=1 to all their pages before anyone's released a sandbox-supporting browser, and therefore prevent it ever being supported)
Perhaps sites will resort to some sort of browser sniffing to determine whether or not text/sandboxed-html is supported
